Award.AwardTitle: Creating an Early Childhood STEM Ecosystem

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This one-year Collaborative Planning project seeks to bring together an interdisciplinary planning team of informal and formal STEM educators, researchers, scientists, community, and policy experts to identify the elements, activities, and community relationships necessary to cultivate and sustain a thriving regional early childhood (ages 3-6) STEM ecosystem. Based in Southeast San Diego, planning and research will focus on understanding the needs and interests of young Latino dual language learners from low income homes, as well as identify regional assets (e.g., museums, afterschool programs, universities, schools) that could coalesce efforts to systematically increase access to developmentally appropriate informal STEM activities and resources, particularly those focused on engineering and computational thinking. This project has the potential to enhance the infrastructure of early STEM education by providing a model for the planning and development of early childhood focused coalitions around the topic of STEM learning and engagement. In addition, identifying how to bridge STEM learning experiences between home, pre-k learning environments, and formal school addresses a longstanding challenge of sustaining STEM skills as young children transition between environments.

The planning process will use an iterative mixed-methods approach to develop both qualitative and quantitative and data. Specific planning strategies include the use of group facilitation techniques such as World Caf√©, graphic recording, and live polling. Planning outcomes include: 1) a literature review on STEM ecosystems; 2) an Early Childhood STEM Community Asset Map of southeast San Diego; 3) a set of proposed design principles for identifying and creating early childhood STEM ecosystems in low income communities; and 4) a theory of action that could guide future design and research. This project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning program, which seeks to advance new approaches to, and evidence-based understanding of, the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
EC[O]STEM, an early childhood STEM-learning ecosystem planning project funded by National Science Foundation grant DLR1743742, engaged parents and community leaders in the process of learning about and designing a STEM-learning ecosystem for children ages three to six in southeast San Diego. In addition to hosting community meetings and conducting focus groups with parents, the project team collected information about the STEM assets in southeast San Diego that are available to young children and their families, and conducted a review of relevant literature. The literature review supports the importance of STEM ecosystems engaging young children and their families in ecosystem efforts.

 

EC[O]STEM contributed to the STEM education knowledge base by adapting Bronfenbrenner's Ecological Systems Theory (BEST) to create a theoretical framework that STEM-learning ecosystems can use to guide their early childhood efforts. The modified BEST framework can be used as a template for creating actionable asset maps, to design and implement network analyses in local communities, and to strategically design STEM ecosystem interventions that have the greatest likelihood of directly impacting young children's STEM development.

 

EC[O]STEM broadened participation in STEM by engaging the broader San Diego STEM ecosystem community in the STEM efforts in southeast San Diego -- a community historically and currently under-represented in San Diego's growing STEM economy. To generate interest and to engage a broad audience in prioritizing STEM education for young children in southeast San Diego the project hosted two public community events with nationally known presenters and early childhood STEM experts. Nonprofit and community leaders as well as local families and educators participated in these events.

 

Through community stakeholder meetings and family focus groups that used a variety of engagement methods such as Live Polling and World Cafe, project staff determined parents were eager to have their young children participate in STEM learning activities that they were not easily able to provide themselves. Parents were most interested in engineering, robotics and coding; and were also interested in participating in parent training that would inform them about how educational systems work in general, and also about how to advocate for STEM education for their children. Further, parents were not only interested in their children participating in early STEM activities, but also wanted to personally learn engineering, coding, and robotics.
